prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO J=6-5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We are observing 12CO J=6-5 in VV 114 using the most compact array configuration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Angular Resolution: We request a resolution of 1.1”, the lowest angular resolution possible in the most compact array that can be input into the OT . We will degrade the resolution to roughly 2.4” to match the resolution of the existing CO data.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 9 to observe 12CO J=6-5 in VV 114. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 8, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~1.7 km/s. The CO line width of VV 114 is ~200 km/s (Sliwa et al. 2013); therefore, a wide bandwidth will ensure we observe the entire line profile. We place two spectral windows on HCO+ and HCN J=8-7; however, we do not expect to detect these weak lines.
Imaging: The primary beam at CO J=6-5 is ~9.1” and does not encompass the entire galaxy. We require a 3 pointing mosaic separated by 1/2 the primary beam. We also require ACA observations to recover the short spacings because VV 114 is an extended source. We are aware that the TP will not be used with band 9 observations requiring the ACA. The ~6.2" largest angular scale recovered by the ACA at 677GHz should be sufficient, as VV 114 has a velocity gradient across the galaxy so that in any given channel, emission across the full 15" extent (VV 114E to VV 114W) is not seen. The quoted largest angular scale in the OT is roughly the size of an individual region such as VV 114E.
Sensitivity: To estimate the required sensitivity, we use the CO J=6-5/3-2 line ratios of Sliwa et al. (2013). VV 114W is seen to have the weakest CO J=3-2 emission with an upper limit to the CO J=6-5/3-2 line ratio of 0.04. We assume the line ratio is half of the upper limit and the peak CO J=3-2 is 1.5K; therefore, we estimate the CO J=6-5 peak to be 30 mK. We require a sensitivity of 10 mK for a 3 sigma detection in VV 114W with a channel width of 40 km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO J=4-3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We are observing 12CO J=4-3 in VV 114 using the most compact array configuration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Angular Resolution: We request a resolution of 1.5”, the lowest angular resolution possible in the most compact array that can be input into the OT . We will degrade the resolution to roughly 2.4” to match the resolution of the existing CO data.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 8 to observe 12CO J=4-3 in VV 114. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 8, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~2.6 km/s. The CO line width of VV 114 is ~200 km/s (Sliwa et al. 2013); therefore, a wide bandwidth will ensure we observe the entire line profile. The remaining three spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum but we still use a fine spectral resolution in case there are any unexpected spectral lines present.
Sensitivity: To estimate the required sensitivity, we use the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008). Papadopoulous et al. (2012) observed several LIRGs in CO J=3-2, J=4-3 and J=6-5 using a single dish telescope. We use the CO J=4-3/3-2 line ratio of 0.9, the smallest line ratio in the sample to be conservative, to estimate the peak of VV 114. The CO J=3-2 peak of the VV 114W, the region with the weakest emission, of 1.5K; therefore, e estimate the peak to be 1.35 K in a 2.4” beam. We assume that the emission is uniform in the beam; therefore, the peak is ~0.5 K in a 1.5” beam. For a 15sigma detection in a 40 km/s, we require a sensitivity of ~0.035 K.
Imaging: The primary beam at CO J=4-3 is ~13.7” and does not encompass the entire galaxy. We require a 2 pointing mosaic separated by 1/2 the primary beam. We also require ACA observations to recover the short spacings because VV 114 is an extended source as seen in the CO J=3-2 map (Figure 1 in Science Justification).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO J=1-0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We are observing 13CO J=1-0 at a resolution of 2.4".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Angular Resolution: We request a resolution of 2.4” to match the lowest resolution of the existing CO data.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 3 to observe 13CO J=1-0 in VV 114. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~5.4 km/s. The CO line width of VV 114 is ~200 km/s (Sliwa et al. 2013); therefore, a wide bandwidth will ensure we observe the entire line profile. One spectral window will be placed on 13CO J=1-0 and the remaining three spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: The 13CO J=1-0 observation of Sliwa et al. (2013) have a similar resolution to that what we request. The sensitivity of the observation was 35 mK and we assume that the peak flux of VV 114W, the region with no detected emission, is equivalent to the sensitivity of the published observation; therefore, we request a sensitivity of 7 mK with a channel width of 40 km/s to detect the line at a 5 sigma level.
Imaging: ACA observations are not required of 13CO J=1-0.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO J=2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We are observing 13CO J=2-1 at a resolution of 2.4".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Angular Resolution: We request a resolution of 2.4” to match the lowest resolution of the existing CO data.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 6 to observe 13CO J=2-1 in VV 114. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~2.7 km/s. The CO line width of VV 114 is ~200 km/s (Sliwa et al. 2013); therefore, a wide bandwidth will ensure we observe the entire line profile. One spectral windown will be centered on 13CO J=2-1 and the remaining three spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We assume a line ratio of 13CO J=2-1/1-0 of 0.6 (Sliwa et al. 2013). Therefore, using the sensitivity required for 13CO J=1-0, we require a sensitivity of 4 mK with a channel width of 10 km/s for a 5 sigma detection.
Special Constraints: If we use a channel width of 40 km/s as with the 13CO J=1-0 observations, the overhead time is greater than 30%; therefore, we decrease the channel width to 10 km/s which increases the total time of the observation.
Imaging: ACA observations are not required of 13CO J=2-1 because 13CO is usually more compact than 12CO. The largest angular scale seen for 12CO J=3-2 is ~15" but we expect teh largest angular scale for 13CO to be less than the largest angular scale recovered (i.e. <12").

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe the luminous infrared galaxy VV 114 in 12CO J=4-3 and J=6-5 to study the distribution of the warm molecular gas. VV 114 has been observed in 12CO J=6-5 with the Submillimeter Array; however, only one out of the three distinct regions of molecular gas concentrations was detected. Our goal is to detect all three regions and to constrain the physical conditions of the warm molecular gas. We also propose to observe 13CO J=1-0 and J=2-1 to detect all three regions and to do a radiative tranfer analysis across the entire galaxy to look for variations in the 12CO-to-13CO abundance ratio.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University
